name: Northern Bladderwort

Identifying Characteristics: Leaves: finely fork divided, flattened, serrated, alternately arranged
Flowers: midsummer, yellow, snapdragon-like emergent on stalk
Other: tiny lopsided sack-like bladders (used to capture prey) attached directly to leafless stems, carnivorous: capture small prey such as zooplankton or small insects
Habitat: Lakes, ponds, slow-moving streams, wetland pools
Range: Native Range: Maine, much of New England, some other parts of the United States

tags: plants with finely-divided leaves on stems
